The wave equation is a partial differential equation that describes the propagation of waves, such as sound waves or electromagnetic waves. It is a fundamental equation in physics and engineering, and has many applications in fields such as acoustics, optics, and seismology.

For the two-dimensional wave equation, each point in the $xy$-plane has an associated real-numbered value, and this collection of values evolves through time. I've used a color map where red indicates a positive value, blue indicates a negative value, and white indicates zero. The applet below simulates a dipole, where the wave equation has two point sources with opposite phase.






Let's make this more precise. In mathematical notation, the values of this heatmap can be represented by a function in three variables: the two spatial variables $x$ and $y$, and the time variable $t \ge 0$. We can denote this by $f(x, y, t)$. The wave equation is the partial differential equation which indicates how the function changes over time and space every inside the domain: $$\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial t}\right)^2f = \left(\frac{\partial}{\partial x}\right)^2f + \left(\frac{\partial}{\partial y}\right)^2f$$ One also needs boundary conditions to specify the values of the function at the boundary of the domain. One example of boundary conditions is to specify point sources $(x, y)$ where the function value varies sinusoidally, i.e. goes as $A\cos(\omega (t + \phi))$ for some amplitude $A$, frequency $\omega$, and phase $\phi$. Such points can be viewed as sources for propagating waves. In the example above, we have two point sources which are fully out-of-phase with each other (i.e. phase difference $\pi$).

When a line of point sources with amplitude zero are placed, they act as a reflector for incoming waves. (TODO Make another demo)

As mentioned in the opening paragraph, electromagnetic radiation (such as light) and sound propagate as waves. There is another familiar model we use for envisioning light, namely as rays. An often-quoted fact about ellipses is that multiple rays emanating at the same speed from one focus and reflecting off the ellipse will all simultaneously converge at the other focus. The analogous statement for a parabola is that multiply rays emanating at the same speed from the focus and reflecting off the parabola will then end up traveling parallel to the axis of symmetry, all lying on a line perpendicular to said axis.





Does this behavior hold when the ray-model is replaced by the wave-model? More generally, how much does qualitative intuition carry over between the two models? There are definitely behaviors which differ between the two models: for example, light and sound cannot bend around a corner in the ray model, but they can in the wave model. (TODO example) The double-slit experiment, which demonstrates the existence of wave interference, is the prototypical example of qualitative behavior which is captured by the wave model and not by the ray model.
